title-group.article-title: The fault detection and diagnosis in rolling element bearings using frequency band entropy

article-meta.aff: State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, China

author-notes.corresp: Tao Liu, State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan Road, Shanghai 200240, China. Email: ynliutao@hotmail.com

abstract.p: In vibration analysis, fault feature extraction from strong background noises is of great importance. Frequency band entropy based on short-time Fourier transform illustrates the complexity of every frequency component in the frequency domain, and it can be used to detect the periodical components hidden in the signal. This article shows how the frequency band entropy offers a robust way in detecting faults even when the signal is under strong masking noises. Furthermore, frequency band entropy provides a way of blindly designing optimal band-pass filters. The filtering signal combined with envelope analysis is helpful in fault diagnosis. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated on both simulated and actual data from rolling bearings.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Bearing is one of the fundamental and most important components in rotary machine. If the bearing faults occur, it might lead to downtime or even casualties. The key issue in bearing diagnosis is how to identify the potential faults inside a operating machine accurately.1 Vibration signal based methods, the most suitable and effective one for bearing, have received considerable attention and have been applied successively.2

It is vital to extract fault characteristics from the bearing as the basis of fault diagnosis. To date, many different techniques have been developed for feature extraction. These techniques can be classified into time, frequency, and time–frequency domains. These time and frequency domain analyses may be sensitive to different faults, and the features’ periodicity may be suppressed. Classical Fourier method is sensitive to the background noises because it tends to average out transient vibrations.3 So, the entropy of the spectrum is introduced in vibration signal processing. Information theory depicts the complexity of the signal and was first proposed by Shannon;4 this has been applied as a measure of disorder, unevenness of distribution, and the degree of dependency of a system.5 Spectral entropy is an extension of information entropy in frequency domain, which has been used in mechanical vibration monitoring and many other fields.6–8 Classical amplitude spectral entropy reveals the spectral complexity of a signal, but it cannot discover the hidden periodicity of every frequency component. Antoni and co-workers9–11 introduced the spectral kurtosis (SK) in rotating machine’s signal processing. As a statistical fourth-order spectrum analysis tool, the SK can indicate the presence of series of transients and their locations in the frequency domain.12 However, a high value of SK requires that the individual transients are separated.8 In this article, the frequency band entropy (FBE) is introduced to illustrate the complexity of every frequency component in time–frequency domain (time variance). FBE expresses the entropy at every frequency component, thereby the result of FBE can be utilized to describe the complexity of one frequency component.

When faults occur in the rolling bearing, the interaction between the rolling element surface and the fault parts should bring about a series of impact signals, which in turn will cause the transient vibration signals. The FBE is larger if the energy variation of one frequency component is uniform. On the contrary, while the changing of the frequency component energy is more regular, the FBE is lower. For instance, the complexity of resonance frequency in time–frequency domain (time variance) is often lower than others. Also, the feature is very suitable for band-pass filter designing. Envelope is an effective method in extracting the bearing defect frequency components.13–15 While in vibration analysis, the incipient fault is usually weak and the information is always masked under strong background noise. Hence, it is better to filter the signal prior to the envelope analysis. In this study, FBE provides an automatically optimal parameter designing of the band-pass filter. Then, the signal is applied to envelope spectrum analysis in bearing fault feature extraction. It is obvious that the bearing characteristic frequencies are quite clear for further diagnosis.

This article is organized as follows. In ‘Technical background’ section, the proposed method is presented after introducing the short-time Fourier transform (STFT), amplitude spectral entropy, FBE, and envelope spectrum analysis. The ‘Simulation analysis validation’ section illustrates parameter selection and validity of the proposed method with a simulated signal. Then, in the ‘Experiment validation’ section, two experiment bearing signals are analyzed based on FBE and envelope demodulation. The final section gives the conclusion from the above results.

sec.title: Technical background
sec.p: Classical amplitude spectral entropy reveals the spectral complexity of the signal; however, it cannot discover the hidden periodicity of every frequency. FBE depicts every frequency component’s complexity in the time–frequency domain. ‘STFT’ and ‘Amplitude spectral entropy’ are the basis of FBE; so, they are introduced briefly. Then, the proposed method is defined in ‘Frequency band entropy’ section. Subsequently, ‘Envelope spectrum analysis’ is explained and the optimal ‘Envelope spectrum analysis based on FBE’ presented.

sec.title: Short-time Fourier transform
sec.p: It is crucial to recognize time–frequency in discovering the time and frequency transform of the signal. STFT gave a measure of the sinusoidal frequency and phase content of a signal as a function of time and has been introduced in many fields.

Simply, given the time signal x(t), and the function of STFT can be computed by the following equation (1)STFT{x(t)}=X(τ,ω)=∫-∞+∞x(t)ω(t-τ)e-jωtdt where ω(t) is the window function, commonly a Hanning window.

sec.title: Amplitude spectral entropy
sec.p: The amplitude spectral can be used to measure the distribution of frequencies.16 Suppose that X(i),i=1,2,…,N is the amplitude spectrum of signal x(t); then, the normalized spectral entropy can be defined as (2){Hs=-(∑i=1Npiln(pi))ln(N)pi=X(i)∑j=1NX(j)∑i=1Npi=1 where Hs is the amplitude spectral entropy.

It is obvious that Hs depicts the complexity and uniformity of the spectrum distribution. The probability pi describes the ith frequency’s percentage in whole spectrum and P={p1,p2,…,pN} only depends on the distribution of the frequency components X. Thus, the spectral entropy can be used to evaluate the spectral structure of the signal. When amplitudes of each frequency component are equal i.e., p1=p2=…=pN=1/N, the maximum spectrum entropy is equal to 1. On the contrary, if amplitudes focus on few frequency components, while all other frequencies are impossible to occur, the spectral entropy is equal to zero. So, the range of spectral entropy defined in equation (2) is [0,1].16,17

sec.title: Frequency band entropy
sec.p: The spectral entropy reveals the spectrum complexity of the signal, but it cannot display the variety of every frequency component along the time. Hence, based on STFT, we provide the FBE to express every frequency component’s complexity in the time–frequency domain (time variance). The FBE is defined as follows.

First of all, time–frequency domain distribution of signals will be achieved according to the STFT: Suppose x(t) is the signal to be transformed. Considering a sample set X={x1,x2,…,xN},xi∈Rs, the result of STFT can be expressed as (3)TER=[r1,1…r1,C…rM,1…rM,C] where M is the frequency point, C=N/L the Fourier transform times in the whole time T, and L the step in which window moves along the time axis.
Thus, we can describe the amplitude of the kth frequency component fk,k=1,2,…,M along time t (4)X(fk)=(rk,1,rk,2,…,rk,C)

Second, we calculate the average power spectrum as (5)PX(fk)(F)=P{|X(fk;F)|2} =1N|X(fk;F)|2=1N|X(fk)e-jFt|2 where F is the spectrum of frequency component fk in the time–frequency domain. It discovers the periodic energy components hidden in fk.
Furthermore, we can estimate the amplitude spectral entropy of the frequency component fk as follows (6){Hsk=-(∑m=1Cpm,kln(pm,k))ln(C)pm,k=PX(fk)(Fm)∑n=1CPX(ki)(Fn)∑m=1Cpm,k=1
After calculating the amplitude spectral entropy of every frequency component in the time–frequency domain, the FBE will be introduced as follows (7)Hsf=(Hs1,Hs2,…,HsM)

From the above definition of FBE, we can obtain the complexity of each frequency component. The term pm,k describes the mth frequency’s percentage of frequency component fk in power spectrum. In particular, the change of energy is suspected to vary periodically; then, the value of FBE will be lower, or larger if the frequency band energy fluctuates randomly in the time–frequency domain (time variance).

The FBE can be used to estimate the cyclostationary signal and get hold of the resonance band of the signal.18 The issue is employed in signal processing to blindly identify a detection filter, and the center frequency of the filter is achieved at the frequency where the FBE value is minimum. This frequency is defined as H=min(Hsf). Because the FBE is calculated based on STFT, the center frequency is influenced by the window length Nw. Hence, in order to confirm the center frequency, different entropies will be estimated which correspond to several window lengths. Also, the f0 with the minimum entropy is the center frequency of the filter. On the other hand, Nw will be used to evaluate the band-pass frequency of the filter. For instance, the frequency band Δf can be estimated as Δf≈1.5fs/Nw,10 where fs is the sample rate. This result is of great importance for practical application; more will be explained in the following section.19,20

sec.title: Envelope spectrum analysis
sec.p: Envelope spectrum based on Hilbert transform has been widely applied in bearing fault detection.15 It can be used to calculate the bearing characteristic frequencies from high resonance frequency. The envelope signal E(t) of original signal x(t) is defined as follows (8){E(t)=|z(t)|=|x(t)+jh(t)|h(t)=1πtx(t) where h(t) is the Hilbert transform of x(t), which is obtained from the convolution of the function 1/πt and x(t). As it is well known, the Hilbert transform can be regarded as a filter of amplitude unity and phase ±90∘ depending on the sign of the frequency of input signal spectrum. Analytical signal z(t) is the complex signal which is made up of a real part x(t) and an imaginary one h(t). When bearing defections occur, some characteristic frequencies can be obtained by performing spectrum analysis on the envelope signal E(t).21

sec.title: Rolling element bearing vibration frequency features
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows the rolling element bearing’s structure and load distribution. D and d are pitch diameter and ball diameter, respectively, θ the bearing contact angle, and Z the number of rolling body. The shaft rotating frequency fr is only related to the shaft rotating speed n (fr=n/60). Also, fi, fo, fb, and fc are, respectively, ball inner race pass frequency, ball outer race pass frequency, ball rotational frequency, and fundamental cage frequency. Suppose there is only pure rolling between the rolling bodies and raceway (inner or outer race), the possible fault locations and related frequencies are presented in Table 1. Figure 1.

sec.title: Envelope spectrum analysis based on FBE
sec.p:
Although the analysis of the vibration signal based on FBE is feasible and valuable, for example, in detecting the resonance band of the signal, it does not provide any information of the fault itself. In this study, band-pass filter used in envelope spectral frequency band selection is designed blindly according to the FBE. The main steps of this method are as follows.
Calculating the FBE. The time–frequency distribution of the signal can be estimated by means of calculating the power spectrum of the STFT. Then, based on the STFT, power spectral entropy of the signal is calculated. Finally, we can obtain the FBE at all frequency components at different Nw,Nw=2k,k=1,2,3,…,M. Figure 2 shows the FBE analysis based on STFT and amplitude spectral entropy. The algorithm has been illustrated in ‘Frequency band entropy’ section. Some examples of the application will be illustrated in ‘Simulation analysis validation’ section.
Designing the filter. Here, as well, we choose the minimum entropy value and corresponding Nw, and then estimate the filter central frequency f0 and frequency band Δf, where f0 is equal to the frequency in the minimum entropy value and Δf≈1.5fs/Nw. So, a band-pass filter can be designed according to the parameters f0 and Δf.
Envelope spectrum analysis. The test signal is processed previously with the filter designed in step (2); then, we can analyze it by envelope spectrum method.
Figure 2.
Interpretation of the STFT-based FBE analysis. STFT: short-time Fourier transform and FBE: frequency band entropy.

sec.title: Simulation analysis validation
sec.p: A simulated signal of rolling element bearing with inner race defect is applied to demonstrate the proposed method. The feasibility and reliability of FBE in bearing fault analysis is discussed and illustrated.

sec.title: Vibration model of rolling element bearing
sec.p: The early failure of rolling element bearing is often expressed as localized pitting on the inner race, outer race, or rolling bodies. With rotating of the bearing, the shocks will occur between the pitting parts and bearing contacting components. Because the rotating period of the absolute position of the pitting is greater than the period of shock generation, the rolling element bearing vibration signals present the feature of amplitude modulation. For instance, when bearing pitting occurs on the inner race, the absolute position of pitting is rotating with the same speed of the shaft. So, the periodic shocks are modulated by the shaft rotating frequency. It is obvious that the modulation signal frequency is different when the bearing pitting location occurs at the inner race, outer race, and rolling body. Therefore, identification of the modulation signal is helpful in the analysis of rolling element pitting bearings.

Mcfadden and Smith22 proposed a model produced by a single-point defect and extended it to characterize multiple-point defects. The vibration signal of rolling element bearing is complex under the defect state, which is mainly caused by geometry shape, tolerance, shaft speed, load distribution, transfer function, etc.22,23 Previous research showed that rolling element bearing signal is pseudo-cyclostationary in nature because of the random slip between the rolling element and the cage.24 Thus, the rolling element bearing pitting fault model can be expressed as equation (9), which has been validated and applied in describing faults in rolling element bearing.25 (9){x(t)=∑i=1MAis(t-iT-τi)+n(t)Ai=A0cos(2πQt+ϕA)+CAs(t)=e-Btsin(2πfnt+ϕw) where Ai is the amplitude modulation with period 1/Q, s(t) the attenuated damping oscillation with mean impulse period T between the two adjacent shocks, τi the time lag of period T at the ith impact caused by the slip, n(t) the white noise with zero mean, CA the arbitrary constant, A0 the amplitude of the modulating signal which corresponds to the load under the bearing, B the resonance damping coefficient depending on the system, and fn the natural frequency of the system. While the parameters such as the natural frequency fn, shaft rotating frequency fr (fr=1/Q), time lag τi, and damping coefficient B are defined, the fault rolling element bearing signal can be simulated according to equation (9). By analyzing the amplitude spectrum of the simulating signal, we can identify where the defect occurs. For convenience of calculation, we consider the phases ϕA and ϕw to be equal to zero, and more will be introduced in ‘Simulation and analysis’ section.

sec.title: Simulation and analysis
sec.p:
Inner race defect is simulated according to equation (9). The parameters of simulation signal are as follows: the sampling frequency fs is 12 kHz, the natural frequency fn 3 kHz, the shaft rotating frequency fr 28 Hz, and the inner race frequency fi 79 Hz. The τi is 0.01 and the data length of signal is 10,240. Figure 3(a) is the raw signal and Figure 3(b) displays the filtered time wave; the filter was designed by means of the FBE. The envelope spectrum of raw data is presented in Figure 4(a), and it is obvious that there are some harmonic frequencies besides the characteristic frequency fp and rotating frequency fr. In practical application, it is confounded in finding the fault frequency components. Figure 4(b) reveals the envelope spectrum after filtering. It can be seen from the figure that the characteristic frequencies fr and fp are more visible than the spectrum in Figure 4(a). Figure 3.
Simulated signal with inner race defect: (a) time wave of original signal and (b) time wave of the filtered signal, the filter parameters of which are decided by FBE. FBE: frequency band entropy.
Figure 4.
Envelope spectrum: (a) raw data and (b) signal after band-pass filter.

Figure 5(a) is the power spectral density (PSD) of simulated signal and it is clear that the characteristic frequencies cannot be found. Figure 5(b) displays the FBE which corresponds to window lengths Nw=16,32,64,128,and 256 (spectral resolution of 750, 375, 188, 94, and 47 Hz per line). The estimation of the FBE has been explained in ‘Frequency band entropy’ section. In all cases, the FBE clearly reveals the complexity of the spectrum energy. Furthermore, the minimal value of every FBE is 3 kHz which is obviously corresponding to the resonance frequency. The entropy of natural frequency fn is decreased at the window length Nw = 16–128 but increased at Nw=256. This is due to the fact that increasing of the Nw brings about the decreasing of the signal-to-noise ratio. So, we choose Nw*=128 to design the band-pass filter and the filter parameters are f0=3000 Hz and frequency band Δf is equal to 1.5*fs/Nw*=140.6 Hz. Finally, the band-pass filter is presented in Figure 5(c). The normalized FBE reciprocal is adopted in order to match the filter designing. The envelope spectrum of the filtered signal presented in Figure 4(b) demonstrates the feasibility and validity of utilizing the FBE in detecting bearing faults. Figure 5.
(a) PSD; (b) FBE computed in different frequency resolutions (Nw=16,32,64,128,and 256) (The analyzed signal is from a rolling element bearing simulated with an inner race fault.); and (c) normalized FBE reciprocal and optimal band-pass filter with f0=3000 Hz and Δf=140.6 Hz. PSD: power spectral density and FBE: frequency band entropy.

sec.title: Experiment equipment
sec.p: To investigate the effectiveness of the proposed approach for bearing fault diagnosis, two cases are considered in this study. These cases have different experimental environments which include normal bearing data and inner race and outer race fault data. The detailed information of the two cases are as follows.

Case I: This experiment data is from Case Western Reserve University26 The experiment equipment consists of a Reliance Electric 2H IQPreAlert connected to a dynamometer. Signal point faults with sizes 0.007, 0.014, and 0.021 in, motor loads 0–3 HP, and motor speeds 1720–1797 r/min were introduced to the test bearings (6205-2RS JEM SKF in drive-end), and the defects were processed by electro-discharge machining. These faults were introduced separately at inner race, outer race, and rolling elements. These fault vibration signals were measured by the accelerometers mounted on the outer motor hosing with magnetic bases. Data were collected with 12 kHz sampling rate.

Case II: The experiment equipment consisted of rolling bearing test rig and data acquisition system. The schematic diagram of test rig is shown in Figure 6. The test rig includes rotor driver, fixing frame, and support. The shaft of machine is driven by an AC motor through a rub belt and a shaft belt coupling, and supported by a rotor back-up device. Test bearing is fitted on the shaft. The outer race of the bearing is fixed by a clamping device and inner race rotates with the shaft. The rotating speed of the shaft is 720 r/min. Figure 7 shows the real test equipment and data acquisition system. Data acquisition system is made up of acceleration sensors, a NI PXI-4472 data acquisition card, and acquisition software which is programmed with NI LabVIEW. The test bearing type is 6203; bearing parameters and operation condition are presented in Table 2. A slight outer race single-point fault is introduced to the corresponding surface of the test bearing by electrical-discharge machining method. The sampling frequency is 25.6 kHz. The characteristic frequencies of the rolling element bearing 6023 are presented in Table 3. After fitting the fault bearing on the test rig, the bearing rotates on the test rig, and vibration data are collected by the data acquisition system. There are 30 data sets are collected and the duration of each data set is 0.8 s. Figure 6.

sec.title: Results and analysis
sec.p:
In case I, the normal bearing data are processed according to FBE and envelope analysis. In this article, we analyze the data of the normal bearing for which load is 1 HP and motor speed is about 1772 r/min. For inner race fault bearing, the data for which the fault diameter is 0.007 in, motor load 0, and motor speed 1797 r/min are analyzed. For the outer race fault, we select the data for which the load is 1 HP, fault diameter 0.007 in, and motor speed 1772 r/min. In fact, as a modulation signal, the motor rotating frequency is more prominent in the amplitude spectrum with increase of loading or fault diameter. Furthermore, when motor speed is determined, the motor rotating frequency is stable. Figure 8(a) is the envelope spectrum of signal without filtering; it is difficult to find the characteristic frequencies because there are some high peaks in the bands 0–100 Hz and 900–1000 Hz. However, the fr which is equal to 29.3 Hz is clearly displayed in Figure 8(b), which is approximately equal to the motor rotating frequency. The filter center frequency f0=1125 Hz and the band-pass frequency is from 984 to 1266 Hz ([f0-1.5Δf/2,f0+1.5Δf/2] and Δf≈fs/Nw*=188 Hz), which has been illustrated in ‘Frequency band entropy’ section. The choice of the filter center frequency and band are according to the FBE which has been presented in Figure 8(c). The optimal parameter Nw* is equal to 64. Figure 9 is the filter envelope spectrum of the inner race fault bearing. Figure 10 as well displays the filtering envelope spectrum of the outer race defect bearing. It is obvious that the fault information can be obtained from envelope spectrum analysis with optimal band-pass filtering data. Figure 9.
Envelope spectrum of the inner race fault bearing with characteristic frequencies fi=161.7 Hz, fr=30.47 Hz, and Nw*=64.
Figure 8.
Envelope spectrum of the normal bearing: (a) is the envelope spectrum without filtering; (b) the envelope spectrum after filtering; and (c) FBE and the minimum value. FBE decided the filter frequency f0=1125 Hz. Spectral resolution is 188 Hz per line. FBE: frequency band entropy.
Figure 10.
Envelope spectrum of the outer race fault bearing with characteristic frequencies fo=105.5 Hz, fr=29.3 Hz, and Nw*=64.

In case II, a slight outer race defect bearing signal with strong background noises is acquired. The time waveform of the signal before and after filtering are presented in Figure 11(a) and (b). The optimal band-pass filter was blindly designed, which has been explained in ‘Technical background’ section. Also, the corresponding filtered signals show that there are many periodic impulses in the time wave. It is due to the defections in the outer race of the bearing, which result in the impactions between the rolling element surface and fault part. Because the defection is weak, the shaft rotating will lead to modulating the fault frequency. Figure 12 shows the envelope spectrum before and after filtering. It can be seen from Figure 12(a) that the frequencies are masked by the strong background noises and it is hard to identify the characteristic frequencies. The rotating frequency fr=12.25 Hz and ball pass frequency of the outer ring fo=37.63 Hz are clearly revealed in Figure 12(b). Because the decrease in the FBE discovers the periodic components in the signal spectrum, the value of the FBE can be introduced to optimize filter designing, and the filtering signal corresponding to the resonance frequency band can help us to separate the periodic spectral components from the strong background noise. Figure 11.
Time waveform of the signal before (a) and after (b) filtered.
Figure 12.
Envelope spectrum: (a) fault signal and (b) signal after optimal band-pass filter, the design parameters of which are obtained from the FBE (Nw*=128). FBE: frequency band entropy.
The analysis results of the experimental data verify the validity and effectiveness of the proposed method in extracting the fault diagnostic information blindly from the strong background noise.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article demonstrates the definition and properties of the FBE and discusses the application of FBE in vibration monitoring of rotating machines. FBE is an effective tool in detecting weak and incipient faults which are often masked in background noises. In order to identify the faults, we introduce the FBE to ascertain in which frequency band the defection is the best contrast to background noises. Then, the optimal band-pass filter based on the FBE parameters is designed. Finally, the filtered signal is analyzed by calculating the envelope spectrum. The validity of the method has been demonstrated in both simulated and experimental signals. It can be seen from the analysis results that the characteristic frequencies of the bearing faults can be clearly obtained from the raw data. The advantage of the proposed method lies in the fact that it can blindly find out which frequency band should be processed. In fact, the automatically optimizing the parameters used in envelope analysis is helpful in bearing fault diagnosis. This result is important in practical applications. In order to obtain the time variance complexity of the frequency components, the STFT-based FBE is introduced in the article, while it is only a simple estimator of the FBE available to date. How to increase the stability of FBE and reduce the filter error is worthy to be studied further.
